    AI imperatives and risks

    • Agentic AI
    • AI Governanace Platforms
    • Disinformation Security

    New frontier of computing

    • Post-Quantum Cryptograhpy
    • Ambient Invisible Intelligence
    • Energy-Effcient Computing
    • Hybrid Computing

    Human-machine synergy

    • Spatial Computing
    • Polyfunctional Robots
    • Neurogical Enhancement

    Theme No. 1: AI imperatives and risks drive organizations to protect themselves

    Trend 1:Â Agentic AI:Â Autonomous AI can plan and take action to achieve goals set by the user.

    • Business benefits:Â A virtual workforce of agents to assist, offload and augment the work of humans or traditional applications.
    • Challenges:Â Requires robust guardrails to ensure alignment with providersâ€™ and usersâ€™ intentions.

    Trend 2: AI governance platforms:Â Technology solutions enable organizations to manage the legal, ethical and operational performance of their AI systems.

    • Business benefits:Â Create, manage and enforce policies that ensure responsible use of AI, explain how AI systems work, model lifecycle management, and provide transparency to build trust and accountability.
    • Challenges:Â AI guidelines vary across regions and industries, making it difficult to establish consistent practices.

    Trend 3:Â Disinformation security:Â An emerging technology category aimed at systematically discerning trust.

    • Business benefits:Â Decreases fraud by strengthening controls for validating identity; prevents account takeover through continuous risk scoring, contextual awareness and a continuous adaptive trust model; and protects brand reputation by identifying harmful narratives.
    • Challenges:Â Requires a continuously updated, multilayered, adaptive learning, team approach.

    Theme No. 2: New frontiers of computing prompt organizations to reconsider how they compute

    Trend 4:Â Post-quantum cryptography (PQC):Â Data protection that is resistant to quantum computing (QC) decryption risks.

    • Business benefits:Â Protects data from the security risks that will come with the advent ofÂ quantum computing.
    • Challenges:Â PQC algorithms are not drop-in replacements for existing asymmetric algorithms. Current applications may have performance issues, will require testing and may need to be rewritten.

    Trend 5:Â Ambient invisible intelligence:Â Technology unobtrusively integrated into the environment to enable a more natural, intuitive experiences

    • Business benefits:Â Enables low-cost, real-time tracking and sensing of items, improving visibility and efficiency; potential for unforgeable provenance and new ways for objects to report identity, history and properties.
    • Challenges:Â Providers will have to address privacy concerns and obtain consent for some types of data use. Users may opt to disable tags to preserve privacy.

    Trend 6:Â Energy-efficient computing:Â An approach to increasingÂ sustainabilityÂ through more efficient architecture, code and algorithms; hardware optimized for efficiency; and the use of renewable energy to run systems.

    • Business benefits:Â Address legal, commercial and social pressures to improve sustainability by reducing carbon footprint.
    • Challenges:Â New hardware, cloud services, skills, tools, algorithms and applications will be required; migrating to new computing platforms will be complex and expensive; energy prices may rise in the short term as green energy demand increases.

    Trend 7: Hybrid computing:Â Combines different compute, storage and network mechanisms to solve computational problems.

    • Business benefits:Â Highly efficient, high-speed, transformative innovation environments; AI that performs beyond current technological limits; autonomous businesses powered by higher levels of automation; augmented human capability allowing real-time personalization at scale and use of the human body as a computing platform.
    • Challenges:Â Nascent, highly complex technologies require specialized skills; a system of autonomous modules introduces security risks; involves experimental technologies and high costs; need for orchestration and integration.

    Theme No. 3: Human-machine synergy brings together the physical and digital worlds

    Trend 8:Â Spatial computing:Â Digitally enhances the physical world using technologies like augmented and virtual reality to offer immersive experiences.

    • Business benefits:Â Addresses consumer demand for immersive and interactive experiences in gaming, education and e-commerce; satisfies demand for sophisticated visualization tools for decision making and efficiency in healthcare, retail and manufacturing.
    • Challenges:Â Head-mounted displays are expensive and unwieldy, require frequent charging, isolate users and may increase the potential for accidents; user interfaces are complex; data privacy and security are major concerns.

    Trend 9:Â Polyfunctional robots:Â Robots capable of performing multiple tasks and seamlessly switching between them as required.

    • Business benefits:Â Improved efficiency; faster ROI; no need for architectural changes or bolt-down infrastructure means fast deployment, low risk and scalability; can substitute for or work with humans.
    • Challenges:Â The industry hasnâ€™t yet standardized on price or minimum functionality required.

    Trend 10:Â Neurological enhancement:Â Improving cognitive abilities with technologies that read and decode brain activity.

    • Business benefits:Â Human upskilling, safety improvements, personalized education, allowing older people to work longer, next-generation marketing..
    • Challenges:Â Initially expensive, limited battery and options for mobility and wireless connectivity; invasive and risky; UBMIs and BBMIs interface directly with the human brain, creating security challenges; ethical concerns (e.g., altering usersâ€™ perception of reality).
